required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Predictive Properties of the Hyperventilation Provocation Test for the Diagnosis of the Hyperventilation Syndrome
clinical_study.official_title: Predictive Properties of the Hyperventilation Provocation Test for the Diagnosis of the Hyperventilation Syndrome

brief_summary.textblock:
The Hyperventilation Provocation Test (HPTest) associated with end-tidal CO2 pressure (PETCO2) measurement is a diagnostic tool for idiopathic hyperventilation syndrome (HVS). However, interpretation of HPTest remains unclear regarding the relevant PETCO2 values to consider and the occurrence of subjective symptoms.
This case-control study aims to identify accurate HPTest measurements for the diagnosis of HVS, regardless of symptoms occurrence.

detailed_description.textblock:
The investigators will analyze in a retrospective way HPTest datas from 74 subjects, involving 37 subjects with complaints and a Nijmegen questionnaire score of ≥23/64 (HVS+) matched on gender, age, height, weight and BMI category with 37 healthy controls without complaints and a Nijmegen questionnaire score of <23/64 (HVS-)(16).
To rule out confounding respiratory pathology, each participant will have completed spirometry and methacholine testing, that will have a result within expected normal values.
All data will have to be collected by the same equipment and by the same operators in the pulmonology department of the CHU-St Pierre-Brussels between September 2015 and December 2020.
Kinetics of the PETCO2 recorded during each of the 3 phases of the HPTest (adaptation, hyperventilation and recovery) will be mathematically modeled by an curvilinear model with the parameters (A, A', a and a') noted from the kinetic equation (TAU) : TAU [PETCO2(t)〖=A+a(1-exp〗^((b-t)/c))]. For any observed differences in parameters between groups, the Area Under Curves will be estimated at the cut-off that offers the best Sensitivity and Specificity.
The probability of a type I error is set at 5%.

primary_outcome.description: PetCO2 at the end (5th minute) of the recovery phase of the HPTest

secondary_outcome.description: PetCO2 at the end (3d minute) of the recovery phase of the HPTest

arm_group.description: Subjects without documented respiratory or cardiac disease, with a spirometry and metacholine tests within expected values AND with complaints documented by a Nijmegen questionnaire score of ≥23/64 (suspected of idiopathic hyperventilation)

Healthy controls without documented respiratory or cardiac disease, with a spirometry and metacholine tests within expected values AND without complaints documented by a Nijmegen questionnaire score of <23/64

intervention.description: During the HPTest, the subject is comfortably seated in a chair with armrests and breathes in a mouthpiece with a salivary collector and a nasal clamp. Parameters of ventilation and gas exchange are analyzed via an Oxycon ProTM (SN808008) with TripleV-Volume Sensor digital(Jaeger). The HPTest begins with a 3-minutes adaptation phase during which the patient is asked to "breathe normally". During the 3-minutes of voluntary hyperventilation phase, the patient is asked to increase his tidal volume and support a breath rate of at least 30/min in order to reduce his PETCO2 by at least 50%. During the recovery phase of the HPTest, the patient is invited to regain a "natural breathing" for 5 minutes, without guidance on tidal volume or breath rate.

study_pop.textblock: Patients who visited the pulmonary department and performed a HPTest on medical prescription

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Anyone over 18 years of age who has completed an HPTest and a Nijmegen questionnaire between 2015 and 2020
Exclusion Criteria:
-
